title: Daily Evening Bhagavatam Discourse | HH Stoka Krishna Swami | SB 1.9.19 | 16-04-2022
speaker: HH Stoka Krishna Swami

segments.key_quote: Krishna is known very confidentially as the Supreme Personality of God only through pure devotional service.
segments.summary: Bhishmadeva explains that Krishna's glories are known confidentially through direct contact by pure devotees engaged in transcendental loving service, who experience different rasas in their relationship with Him.

segments.key_quote: Bhishmadeva himself is one of the Mahajanas, he has mentioned only three important names of the twelve who know the glories of the Lord.
segments.summary: The lecture identifies the twelve Mahajanas, great devotees of the Lord, and notes that Bhishmadeva, himself one of them, only mentions three names in the verse.

segments.key_quote: As we progress in devotional service, more and more revelation about Krishna, the Supreme Personality of Godhead, happens within our heart, within our consciousness.
segments.summary: The speaker explains how devotional service leads to a better understanding of Krishna, culminating in the stage of bhava, where one understands the absolute nature of Krishna and experiences ecstasy.

segments.key_quote: Anubhava is appreciated by the devotee in ecstasy.
segments.summary: The lecture elaborates on anubhava, a subdivision of bhava, characterized by ecstasy and physical symptoms like perspiring and trembling, using the example of Yashoda binding Krishna with a rope.

segments.key_quote: The glories of the Lord which are exhibited in this being subordinated before his devotees is another feature of the glories of the Lord.
segments.summary: The speaker discusses Krishna's relationship with Arjuna, highlighting how Krishna assumes a subordinate position as Arjuna's chariot driver out of love, showcasing another aspect of His glories.

segments.key_quote: The Lord says, I put my devotee into difficulty and thus the devotee becomes more purified in exchanging transcendental bhava with me.
segments.summary: The lecture concludes by explaining that the difficulties experienced by devotees, like the Pandavas, are not material problems but opportunities for exchanging transcendental bhava with the Lord and becoming purified.
